exodus — I/O of ExodusII Databases¶

affect.exodus¶

This module contains the classes for reading/writing an ExodusII format mesh database.

Usage and Data Model¶

The fundamental class for I/O is Database. Though it can be directly used, there is a convenient DatabaseFile context manager.

Access to the stored values and the structure of the Database is through objects of the following classes:

DatabaseFile(self, path[, mode]) A context manager for opening and using a Database.
Database(path[, mode]) An Exodus database for reading/wring Exodus format files.
Global(self[, database_id]) Initialize the global entity on a Database which acts as an BaseEntityCollection with only a single Entity member, which is itself.
Field(self, name, components[, variables, …]) A field name, number and name of components, and the ExodusII variable ID for each component.
FieldArray A multidimensional array of double precision, which is a specialization of NumPy array.
Fields(self, parent_entity_collection) An accessor for fields, acting as an ordered dictionary with some extra member functions.
Nodal(self[, database_id]) Initialize the Nodal entity on a Database which acts a both an entity, and a list of entities, whose sole member is itself.
Blocks(self[, database_id, block_type]) The collection of all Block entities of a specific type on a Database.
Block(self[, database_id, block_type, …]) A block of entries — elements, faces, or edges of the same topology — with connectivity information.
Maps(self[, database_id, map_type]) The collection of all Maps of a specific type in a Database.
Map(self[, database_id, map_type, map_id, …]) A map entity.
Sets(self[, database_id, set_type]) A collection of all the Set entities of a specific type on a Database.
Set(self[, database_id, set_type, set_id, …]) A set of entries in a Database.

See also the Exodus data model Glossary for more information.

Array Data and Internal Memory Buffers¶

Wherever possible, native array data from the ExodusII C API is accessed directly without copying through a view on a numpy.ndarray. This maintains performance by eliminating copying, and it supplies the arrays in a convenient form for computations with numpy or scipy functions.

Some methods in this module, however, require allocating a smaller temporary memory buffers for working space. These buffers are small and the size is noted in the documentation for each method. Typical examples of the temporary memory buffer include functions required to translate Exodus C strings to the Python str type, or rearrange integer or floating point arrays in the correct order before supplying them or converting them to numpy.ndarray. Internal temporary buffers are allocated on the C/C++ heap using malloc or equivalent function. The buffer memory is released before the function returns. If an exception occurs, we are careful that the buffer is still released.

Database Objects¶

class affect.exodus.DatabaseFile(self, path, mode=Mode.READ_ONLY)¶

A context manager for opening and using a Database.

Use the with statement while instantiating this class to easily connect to a Database, operate on it, and ensure the Database is closed properly after all read/writes are complete. There is no need to surround your code with a try/finally block in order to ensure the Database is closed after an error occurs.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     coord = e.nodal.coordinates()
>>> # file automatically now closed
Parameters:
  • path (str) – The path to the file to open or create.
  • mode – (default Mode.READ_ONLY) the mode on which to open the database

The mode is one of four exclusive values (which may not be OR’ed together).

mode allowed actions on the database
Mode.READ_ONLY read if it exists but not modify
Mode.READ_WRITE read and/or append and modify if it exists
Mode.CREATE write only if it does not already exist
Mode.REPLACE write and destroy if it already exists
Raises:IOError – if the file given by path cannot be accessed
class affect.exodus.Database(path, mode=Mode.READ_ONLY)¶

An Exodus database for reading/wring Exodus format files.

Opens a connection to a Database object with the given path and mode.

Parameters:
  • path (str) – The path to the file to open or create.
  • mode (Mode) – (default Mode.READ_ONLY) mode with which to act on the database
Raises:
  • FileNotFound – reading a file that does not exist
  • FileExists – if trying to write to existing file without replace mode
  • FileAccess – if the mode is invalid
close(self)¶

Close an existing Exodus file database.

You should never have to call close because it is called automatically when the Database object goes out of scope, that is, when the Database.__del__() method is automatically called.

edge_blocks¶

A property that returns the Blocks dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Block(entity_type = EntityType.EDGE_BLOCK).

edge_maps¶

A property that returns the Maps dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Map(entity_type = EntityType.EDGE_MAP).

edge_sets¶

A property that returns the Sets dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Set(entity_type = EntityType.EDGE_SET).

element_blocks¶

A property that returns the Blocks dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Block(entity_type = ELEM_BLOCK).

Example

Iterate over the elements blocks in a database and print the block ID’s and number of elements in each block.

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     print(f'database has {len(e.element_blocks)} element blocks')
>>>     for block_id, block in e.element_blocks.items():
>>>         print(f'block_{block_id} num_elements = {block.num_entries}')
element_maps¶

A property that returns the Maps dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Map(entity_type = EntityType.ELEM_MAP).

element_sets¶

A property that returns the Sets dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Set(entity_type = EntityType.ELEM_SET).

face_blocks¶

A property that returns the Blocks dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Block(entity_type = EntityType.FACE_BLOCK).

face_maps¶

A property that returns the Maps dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Map(entity_type = EntityType.FACE_MAP).

face_sets¶

A property that returns the Sets dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Set(entity_type = EntityType.FACE_SET).

get_full_group_name(self)¶

Return the full -separated path name of this (self.ex_id) group.

get_group_name(self)¶

Return the name of this group self.ex_id.

get_parent(self)¶

Return the id of parent of this (self.ex_id) group; returns (self.ex_id) if at root.

get_root(self)¶

Return the _id of root group of this (self.ex_id) group; returns self.ex_id if at root.

globals¶

A property that returns the Global object for this database.

The Global includes the number and value of time planes, any global variables, and the total number of entries across all blocks such as the global number of elements and nodes, and global id maps.

Example

Print the number of time steps and global number of nodes of a database.

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     num_time_steps = e.globals.num_times()
>>>     print(f'num_times = {num_time_steps}')
>>>     num_nodes = e.globals.num_nodes()
>>>     print(f'num_nodes = {num_nodes}')
Returns:The singleton Global object for this Database.
info_records¶

A property that returns the information records as a list of text strings.

Uses temporary allocated buffer of size num_records * (8 + cexodus.MAX_LINE_LENGTH + 1) bytes.

Returns:list of Information Data strings
mode¶

Get the mode with which the ExodusII database was opened.

Returns:Mode with which the Database object was opened.
nodal¶

A property that returns the Nodal object on this database for accessing global nodal coordinates, nodal variables, and nodal attributes.

Example

Get a bounding box (minimum, maximum) over all the node coordinates in the database.

>>> import numpy
>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     coord = e.nodal.coordinates()
>>>     min_coord  = numpy.min(coord, axis=0)
>>>     max_coord = numpy.max(coord, axis=0)
node_maps¶

A property that returns the Maps dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Map(entity_type = EntityType.NODE_MAP).

node_sets¶

A property that returns the Sets dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Set(entity_type = EntityType.NODE_SET).

num_children(self)¶

Get the number of groups contained in this group (self.ex_id).

path¶

path – object

qa_records¶

A property that returns the list of of the quality assurance records.

The quality assurance records are returned as one concatenated list of strings, in multiples of four, sequentially:

  1. Code name, an application code that has created or modified the database.
  2. Code QA descriptor, usually the version of the application code.
  3. Date the application code touched the database, in the format MM/DD/YY.
  4. Time the application code touched the database, in the 24 hour format HH:MM:SS.

Example

Print all the quality assurance records in a database.

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo', Mode.READ_ONLY) as e:
>>>     records = e.qa_records
>>>     if len(records):
>>>         print(f'len(qa_records): {len(records)}')
>>>         print('qa records:')
>>>         for record in records:
>>>             print('  {record}')

Uses temporary allocated buffer of size 4 * num_qa_records * (8 + cexodus.MAX_STR_LENGTH + 1) bytes.

Returns:list with length 4 * num_qa_records of quality assurance strings
side_sets¶

A property that returns the Sets dictionary for accessing the collection of entities of Set(entity_type = EntityType.SIDE_SET).

summary(self)¶

Get a human readable string representation of the global parameters of the Database.

This is a shortcut instead of using multiple calls to the Global object.

Returns:String representation of the global parameters with line breaks.
version(self)¶

The version used to create this ExodusII database.

The database version number reflects the version of the ExodusII API library that was used to create the file.

Returns:Floating point number representation of an ExodusII API library version.

Exceptions and Debug Messages¶

The exceptions thrown from this module are a part of the interface just as much as the functions and classes. We define an Error root exception to allow you to insulate yourself from this API. All the exceptions raised by this module inherit from it.

Error Base class for all exceptions raised by this module.
NoMemory Exception raised during a memory error.
FileError Exception related to opening or accessing a file.
FileExists Exception raised if existing file prevents writing.
FileNotFound Exception raised when file cannot be opened.
FileAccess Exception raised for an unexpected file mode.
ReadWriteError Exception raised if an issue occurred reading or writing using the internal ExodusII library API.
InternalError Exception for unexpected internal errors in this module.
InvalidEntityType Exception raised if the type of a specified entity was inappropriate.
ArrayTypeError Exception raised if array or a field is unknown or a mismatched type or dimension.
ArgumentTypeError Exception raised if an argument to a function is not the expected type.
InactiveComponent Exception raised if attempt is made to access inactive or non-existent component of a field.
InactiveEntity Exception raised if attempt is made to access inactive or non-existent entity.
InactiveField Exception raised if attempt is made to access inactive or non-existent field.
InvalidSpatialDimension Exception raised if spatial dimension does not match or is invalid.
NotYetImplemented Exception raised if API function is not yet implemented.
RangeError Exception raised if given entry indices are out of range of existing data.

See also

example code in Error

class affect.exodus.Messages¶

Bases: enum.IntFlag

Flags for specifying what kind of messages are output by the internal ExodusII library.

These can be combined using the bitwise operators (&, |, ^, ~) and the result is an enum.IntFlag member.

value meaning
ABORT Causes internal library fatal errors to force program exit. (Default is off)
DEBUG Certain informational messages will print for debug use. (Default is off)
VERBOSE All error messages will print. (Default is off)
DEFAULT No error messages will print. (Default is on)
affect.exodus.debug_messages(options)¶

Change how internal messages are reported inside the internal Exodus Library API globally for any and all subsequent Database files, and Database operations.

Any messages are written to the stderr device by the internal ExodusII library. Different options change how errors and warnings are written from all Database objects to stderr. The options may be OR’ed together to provide a combination of options.

Consider the alternative context manager DebugMessages.

Example

>>> debug_messages(Messages.DEBUG | Messages.VERBOSE)
>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo', Mode.READ_ONLY) as e:
>>>     coord = e.get_coordinates()
>>> debug_messages(Messages.DEFAULT)
Parameters:options – one or more of Messages values or’ed together.
Returns:The previous value of options internal to the Exodus II API library.
class affect.exodus.DebugMessages(option=Messages.VERBOSE | Messages.DEBUG)¶

Bases: object

A context manager for capturing debug messages from the internal library in Database functions.

Wrap your calls in this context if you are having trouble querying your database and wish to get more debug messages from the internal Exodus library. Use the with statement while instantiating this class to wrap calls to Database member functions. This context manager can be nested within the DatabaseFile context manager.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo', Mode.READ_ONLY) as e:
>>>     # append messages to any exceptions raised
>>>     with DebugMessages as messages:
>>>         coord = e.get_coordinates()
>>>     # debugging turned off now
>>> # file automatically now closed

Upon entering this context, the internal Exodus library is set to DEBUG|VERBOSE options. And any Python exceptions raised as a result of Exodus API issues will have their messages appended with the contents of the Exodus debug and verbose output. Upon exiting the context, the previous values of the verbose or debug options are restored.

An alternative to using this context manager—if messages to stderr are acceptable for your application—is to call debug_messages() with the DEBUG and/or VERBOSE option.

Note

This capability will only work on various Unix platforms. A side effect within this context manager is that any output to the C language stderr device—not only from the Exodus library but any other calls within the scope of the active context manager—is rerouted to a buffer. The stderr device is where the Exodus library writes its debug messages.

Initialize and activate buffering of Exodus API verbose or debug messages.

Parameters:option – options to activate messages, either Messages.VERBOSE or Messages.VERBOSE` | Messages.DEBUG, etc.

Global Entity¶

class affect.exodus.Global(self, database_id=-1, *args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: affect.exodus.EntityCollectionWithVariable, affect.exodus.EntityWithVariable

Initialize the global entity on a Database which acts as an BaseEntityCollection with only a single Entity member, which is itself.

The number of entries in the Global entity is also equal to 1.

Parameters:

database_id (int) – ID of the Exodus database
Variables:
  • ex_id (int) – the ExodusII database ID
  • entity_type (EntityType) – always EntityType.GLOBAL, the type of entity held by this collection
dimension()¶

The spatial dimension of the coordinates in the database.

Return type:int
Returns:integer dimension
field(field, time_step)¶

Read the array of field values of a single field at a time step for all entries.

Uses a temporarily allocated buffer of size num_entries * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the desired field (name and component names)
  • time_step (int) – the time step index, at which the field component values are desired, the first time step is 0; a value of -1 will return the values at the last time step.
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

a byte aligned array of numpy.float64 values with shape (num_entries, len(field.components)), or

None if num_entries == 0 or field is not associated with ExodusII variable indices.
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
field_at_times(field, entry_index, start_time_step, stop_time_step)¶

Read an array of values of a field for a single entry (node, element, edge, face) on a range of time steps.

The entry_index has the following meaning inside this method:

entity_type entry_index
NODAL a global node index
BLOCK local entry index of the associated entries
SET local entry index of the associated entries
GLOBAL ignored

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size num_time * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the desired field (name and component names)
  • entry_index (int) – index of the desired entry in the entity, in range [0, num_entries-1]
  • start_time_step (int) – starting time step, in range [0, num_times]
  • stop_time_step (int) – one past the end of the last time step, use -1 to indicate the final time step
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

array of numpy.float64 values with

shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step, len(field.components)) if len(field.components) > 1, or

shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step) if len(field.components) == 1.
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
field_partial(field, time_step, start_entry, stop_entry)¶

Read an array of values of a single field on a subsection of the entries on an entity.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size (stop_entry - start_entry) * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the field
  • time_step (int) – the time time_step index, which the object variable values are desired, the first time time_step is 0.
  • start_entry (int) – first entry at which field is read, in the range of [0, num_entry-1].
  • stop_entry (int) – one past the end of the last desired entry at which the field is read, in the range of [start_entry+1, num_entry]
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

array with shape (stop_entry - start_entry, len(field.components)) of numpy.double
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
fields¶

A dictionary of fields associated with this collection of entities.

This object is a mapping of field names to Field objects that are active on the collection of entities.

Each field is a grouping of ExodusII variable by common name prefix; the suffix of the variable name (whatever follows the last underscore ‘_’ in the name) becomes a component name.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     print(f'number of nodal fields: {len(e.nodal.fields)}')
>>>     print(f'element field names: {e.globals.fields.keys()}')
>>>     for f in e.element_blocks.fields.values():
>>>         print(f)
Return type:Dict[str, Field]
Returns:A collections.OrderedDict, where keys of the dictionary are field names, and the values of the dictionary are instances of Field.
has_id_map(map_type)¶

Whether an ID map of the given type exists on the database.

Parameters:map_type (EntityType) – type of map, ELEM_MAP, NODE_MAP, EDGE_MAP, or FACE_MAP
Return type:bool
Returns:True or False
Raises:InvalidEntityType – if the map_type is invalid
id_map(map_type)¶

Read the array of global integer IDs for all entries of the given type.

This is the single map of the IDs of elements, nodes, edges, or faces (completely separate from the other list of maps. If no ID map exists, the default enumeration is returned, for example, [0, num_elements] when map_type == ELEM_MAP.

Parameters:map_type (EntityType) – type of map, ELEM_MAP, NODE_MAP, EDGE_MAP, or FACE_MAP
Return type:ndarray
Returns:The map entries array with shape (num_elements,), (num_nodes,), (num_edges,), or (num_faces,); or

None if no entries exist in the database.
Raises:InvalidEntityType – if the map_type is invalid
is_field_active()¶

Read the array of one or zero values indicating whether each entity field exists on this entity.

All variables on Nodal and Global entities are always active. Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer up to the size num_vars * 8 bytes.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:An array with shape len(num_vars,) of type numpy.int32, or

None if no variables are present.
Raises:InactiveComponent – if components of one of the fields are not all active or all inactive.
is_variable_active()¶

Read an array of one or zero values indicating whether each variable exists or not, respectively, for a single associated entity.

All variables on nodal and global entities are always active.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:array of numpy.int32 with shape (num_vars,), or

None if no variables are present.
is_variable_active_all()¶

Read a table of indicating whether each of the variables on this type of entities is active on each entity.

A value of one in a table entry indicate a variable exists, while a value of zero indicates the variable does not exist on an entity.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:Array of type numpy.int32, with shape (num_entity, num_vars), with one or zero entries indicating the variable is active on an entity.

None if no variables are present on any entities of this type.
name(entity_id)¶

Read the name of one entity in an association or collection.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of up to size cexodus.EX_INQ_MAX_READ_NAME_LENGTH + 1 bytes.

Parameters:entity_id (int) – the integer ID of an entity in the association or collection.
Return type:str
Returns:Name of the Set, Block, or Map object, given by the ID, or an empty string if this is a Global or Nodal.
names()¶

Read all the names of the entities in this association or collection.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of up to size num_objects * (8 + cexodus.EX_INQ_MAX_READ_NAME_LENGTH + 1) bytes.

Return type:List[str]
Returns:List of names of all the Set, Block, or Map objects in this collection, or an empty list this is a Global or Nodal or

None if this is a Nodal or Global
num_edges()¶

The global number of edge entries in the database.

Most often the number of edges is zero even when num_nodes or num_elem is positive.

Return type:int
num_elements()¶

The global number of element entries in the database.

Return type:int
num_entries()¶

The number of entries contained within a single collection entity.

For example return the number of elements in an element block, or return number of faces in a face set, etc.

entity_type range of num_entries
GLOBAL 1
NODAL number of global nodes
EDGE_BLOCK, FACE_BLOCK, ELEM_BLOCK number of edges, faces, or elements in the block, respectively
NODE_SET, EDGE_SET, FACE_SET, ELEM_SET number of nodes, edges, faces, or elements in the set, respectively
SIDE_SET number of element sides in the side set
NODE_MAP, EDGE_MAP, FACE_MAP, ELEM_MAP number of global nodes, edges, faces, or elements, respectively
Return type:int
Returns:number of entries associated with the entity
Raises:InvalidEntityType – if entity_type of this collection is invalid or does not support entries
num_faces()¶

The global number of edge entries in the database.

Most often the number of faces is zero even when num_nodes or num_elem is positive.

Return type:int
num_nodes()¶

The global number of node entries in the database.

Return type:int
num_times()¶

The number of time steps on the database.

Return type:int
num_variables()¶

The number of variables associated with all the entities of this type in the database.

Return type:int
Returns:Number of variables active on this entity_type.
sum_entries()¶

Get the total count of all associated entries summed over all collections of entities of this type in the database.

Return type:int
Returns:The count of any and all entries related to entities of this type.
self.entity_type Return value
EntityType.GLOBAL 1 (always)
EntityType.NODAL 1 (always)
EntityType.NODE_MAP sum of count of nodes in all node maps
EntityType.EDGE_MAP sum of count of edges in all edge maps
EntityType.FACE_MAP sum of count of faces in all face maps
EntityType.ELEM_MAP sum of count of elements in all element maps
EntityType.NODE_SET sum of count of nodes in all node sets
EntityType.EDGE_SET sum of count of edges in all edge sets
EntityType.FACE_SET sum of count of faces in all face sets
EntityType.ELEM_SET sum of count of elements in all element sets
EntityType.SIDE_SET (sum of count of elements, sum of count of nodes) in all side sets
times()¶

Read all time values.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:array of type numpy.double with shape (num_times), or

None if no time steps are present.
variable(variable_index, time_step)¶

Read the array of values of a single variable at a given time step.

Parameters:
  • variable_index (int) – index of the desired variable, indices start at 0, in range [0, num_variables-1]
  • time_step (int) – the time step index, which the object variable values are desired, the first time step is 0.
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

array with shape (num_entries,) of type numpy.float64, or

None if there are no entries.
variable_at_times(variable_index, entry_index, start_time_step, stop_time_step)¶

Read the array of values of a single variable on a range of time steps.

The entry_index has the following meaning, for a Nodal entity it is a global node index, for Block and Set this is a the local entry index.

The entry_index is ignored for the Global entity.

Parameters:
  • variable_index (int) – index of the desired variable, indices start at 0, in range [0, num_variables-1]
  • entry_index (int) – index of the desired entry in the Entity, in range [0, num_entries-1]
  • start_time_step (int) – starting time step, in range [0, num_times]
  • stop_time_step (int) – one past the end of the last time step, use -1 to indicate the final time step
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

array with shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step) of numpy.float64 or

None if there are no entries
variable_name(variable_index)¶

The name of a variable associated with this entity_type.

A variable is scalar only. Multiple variables make up a vector or tensor field.

Parameters:variable_index (int) – variable index in the range [0,num_variables - 1]
Return type:str
Returns:Name of the variable with the given index.
variable_names()¶

Read the list of variable names associated with this type of entity.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of up to size num_variables * (8 + cexodus.MAX_STR_LENGTH + 1) bytes.

Return type:List[str]
Returns:List of variable names.
variable_partial(var_index, time_step, start_entry, stop_entry)¶

Read the array of values of a single variable on a subsection of the entries on an entity.

Parameters:
  • var_index (int) – index of the desired variable, indices start at 0, in range [0, num_variables-1]
  • time_step (int) – the time time_step index, which the object variable values are desired, the first time time_step is 0.
  • start_entry (int) – first entry at which variables are read, in the range of [0, num_entry-1].
  • stop_entry (int) – one past the end of the last desired entry at which the variable is read, in the range of [start_entry+1, num_entry]
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

array of type numpy.double with shape (stop_entry - start_entry) or

None if there are no entries.
variables¶

A dictionary of scalar variable names and indices associated with this collection of entities.

This object is a mapping of scalar variable name -> index, that are active on the collection of entities.

Prefer using fields() which is usually more convenient unless you only want one component, because each variable is only a scalar, and maybe a component value of a field vector or tensor.

Example

Get the Z component of a force variable at a single node at all times.

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     node_vars = e.nodal.variables
>>>     fz = e.nodal.variable_at_times(node_vars['AForceZ'], 1, 0, e.globals.times().size)
>>>     print(fz)
Return type:Dict[str, int]
Returns:A collections.OrderedDict, where keys of the dictionary are variable names, and the values of the dictionary are the integer index, or ID of the variable.

Read the attribute names on a single entity.

Attribute names were added to the Exodus API library in version 4.26; databases written earlier than that will return empty strings.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size num_attribute * (8 + cexodus.EX_INQ_MAX_READ_NAME_LENGTH + 1) bytes.

coordinates_displaced(time_step)¶

The sum of the coordinates and displacements at a time step.

This is the coordinate vector (returned by coordinates()) added to the displacement vector (the FieldArray corresponding to displacement_name()) at all nodes at a single time step.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer for coordinate and displacement arrays of size 2 * num_nodes * num_dim * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • time_step (int) – the time step index, at which the nodal displaced coordinate values are desired;
  • first time step is 0; a value of -1 will return the values at the last time step. (the) –
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

array with shape (num_nodes, num_dim), or

None if no displacements exist

coordinates_displaced_partial(time_step, start_entry, stop_entry)¶

The sum of the coordinates and displacements on a range of nodes.

This is the coordinate vector (returned by coordinates()) added to the displacement vector (the FieldArray corresponding to displacement_name()) on the given range nodes at a single time step.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer for coordinate and displacement arrays of size 2 * (stop_entry - start_entry) * num_dim * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • time_step – the time step index, at which the nodal displaced coordinate values are desired, the first time step is 0; a value of -1 will return the values at the last time step.
  • start_entry – first desired node, in the range [0, num_nodes-1].
  • stop_entry – one past the end of the last desired node, in the range [start+1, num_nodes]
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

array of numpy.double with shape (stop_entry - start_entry, num_dim), or

None if no displacements exist.
coordinates_local(local)¶

Read the coordinates specified by the local connectivity of a Block.

Examples

If you require local coordinates for more than one block, it is almost always more efficient to read all the global coordinates in a single read operation and copy them block by block.

Let’s compute the mean coordinates of every element block in the database.

We use the numpy.take() function to index local coordinates from the global coordinates. Use the array of global node IDs from the block’s local connectivity as indices.

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     global_coordinates = e.nodal.coordinates()
>>>     block_iterator = e.element_blocks.connectivity_local_all()
>>>     for key, block, local in block_iterator:
>>>         local_coordinates = global_coordinates.take(local.global_nodes, axis=0)  # use numpy.take()
>>>         print(numpy.mean(local_coordinates, axis=0))

Otherwise, if you do not expect to read any other coordinates outside than those of a single block, use this function. The read operation uses less memory and is probably faster since it reads only the range of data required for the block.

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     block = e.element_blocks[7]
>>>     local_connectivity = block.connectivity_local()
>>>     local_coordinates = e.nodal.coordinates_local(local_connectivity)
>>>     print(numpy.mean(local_coordinates, axis=0))
Parameters:local (LocalConnectivity) – structure specifying the range of local connectivity of a block
Return type:ndarray
Returns:a byte aligned coordinates array (numpy.ndarray[numpy.float64, order=”C”]) local to a block, where shape is (local.global_nodes.size, ndim)
coordinates_partial(start, stop)¶

Read a range of the global node coordinates in an array.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size (stop - start) * 8 bytes.

Parameters:

  • stop (int) – one past the end of the last desired node, in the range [start+1, num_nodes]
Return type:

array of numpy.double with shape (stop - start, num_dim)
Raises:

InvalidSpatialDimension – if the dimension is not in the range [0,3]

field(field, time_step)¶

Read the array of field values of a single field at a time step for all entries.

Uses a temporarily allocated buffer of size num_entries * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the desired field (name and component names)
  • time_step (int) – the time step index, at which the field component values are desired, the first time step is 0; a value of -1 will return the values at the last time step.
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

a byte aligned array of numpy.float64 values with shape (num_entries, len(field.components)), or

None if num_entries == 0 or field is not associated with ExodusII variable indices.
Raises:

field_at_times(field, entry_index, start_time_step, stop_time_step)¶

Read an array of values of a field for a single entry (node, element, edge, face) on a range of time steps.

The entry_index has the following meaning inside this method:

entity_type entry_index
NODAL a global node index
BLOCK local entry index of the associated entries
SET local entry index of the associated entries
GLOBAL ignored

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size num_time * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the desired field (name and component names)
  • entry_index (int) – index of the desired entry in the entity, in range [0, num_entries-1]
  • start_time_step (int) – starting time step, in range [0, num_times]
  • stop_time_step (int) – one past the end of the last time step, use -1 to indicate the final time step
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

array of numpy.float64 values with

shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step, len(field.components)) if len(field.components) > 1, or

shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step) if len(field.components) == 1.
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
field_local(field, time_step, local)¶

The array of field values of a single field at a time step for all nodes specified by the local connectivity of a Block.

Note

If you require local fields for more than one block, it is almost always more efficient to read the global field for all nodes in a single read operation and copy them block by block.

Use the numpy.take() function to index local indices from the global nodes. Use the array of global node IDs from the block’s LocalConnectivity.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the desired field (name and component names)
  • time_step – the time step index, at which the field component values are desired, the first time step is 0; a value of -1 will return the values at the last time step.
  • local (LocalConnectivity) – structure specifying the range of local connectivity of a block
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

a byte aligned array of numpy.float64 values with shape (local.global_nodes.size, len(field.components)), or

None if num_entries == 0 or field is not associated with ExodusII variable indices.
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
field_partial(field, time_step, start_entry, stop_entry)¶

Read an array of values of a single field on a subsection of the entries on an entity.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size (stop_entry - start_entry) * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the field
  • time_step (int) – the time time_step index, which the object variable values are desired, the first time time_step is 0.
  • start_entry (int) – first entry at which field is read, in the range of [0, num_entry-1].
  • stop_entry (int) – one past the end of the last desired entry at which the field is read, in the range of [start_entry+1, num_entry]
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

array with shape (stop_entry - start_entry, len(field.components)) of numpy.double
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
fields¶

A dictionary of fields associated with this collection of entities.

This object is a mapping of field names to Field objects that are active on the collection of entities.

Each field is a grouping of ExodusII variable by common name prefix; the suffix of the variable name (whatever follows the last underscore ‘_’ in the name) becomes a component name.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     print(f'number of nodal fields: {len(e.nodal.fields)}')
>>>     print(f'element field names: {e.globals.fields.keys()}')
>>>     for f in e.element_blocks.fields.values():
>>>         print(f)
Return type:Dict[str, Field]
Returns:A collections.OrderedDict, where keys of the dictionary are field names, and the values of the dictionary are instances of Field.

All variables on Nodal and Global entities are always active. Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer up to the size num_vars * 8 bytes.

All variables on nodal and global entities are always active.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:array of numpy.int32 with shape (num_vars,), or

None if no variables are present.

num_entries()¶

The number of entries contained within a single collection entity.

For example return the number of elements in an element block, or return number of faces in a face set, etc.

entity_type range of num_entries
GLOBAL 1
NODAL number of global nodes
EDGE_BLOCK, FACE_BLOCK, ELEM_BLOCK number of edges, faces, or elements in the block, respectively
NODE_SET, EDGE_SET, FACE_SET, ELEM_SET number of nodes, edges, faces, or elements in the set, respectively
SIDE_SET number of element sides in the side set
NODE_MAP, EDGE_MAP, FACE_MAP, ELEM_MAP number of global nodes, edges, faces, or elements, respectively
Return type:int
Returns:number of entries associated with the entity
Raises:InvalidEntityType – if entity_type of this collection is invalid or does not support entries

self.entity_type Return value
EntityType.GLOBAL 1 (always)
EntityType.NODAL 1 (always)
EntityType.NODE_MAP sum of count of nodes in all node maps
EntityType.EDGE_MAP sum of count of edges in all edge maps
EntityType.FACE_MAP sum of count of faces in all face maps
EntityType.ELEM_MAP sum of count of elements in all element maps
EntityType.NODE_SET sum of count of nodes in all node sets
EntityType.EDGE_SET sum of count of edges in all edge sets
EntityType.FACE_SET sum of count of faces in all face sets
EntityType.ELEM_SET sum of count of elements in all element sets
EntityType.SIDE_SET (sum of count of elements, sum of count of nodes) in all side sets

The entry_index has the following meaning, for a Nodal entity it is a global node index, for Block and Set this is a the local entry index.

The entry_index is ignored for the Global entity.

  • variable_index (int) – index of the desired variable, indices start at 0, in range [0, num_variables-1]
  • entry_index (int) – index of the desired entry in the Entity, in range [0, num_entries-1]
  • start_time_step (int) – starting time step, in range [0, num_times]
  • stop_time_step (int) – one past the end of the last time step, use -1 to indicate the final time step
Return type:

ndarray

array with shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step) of numpy.float64 or

None if there are no entries

variables¶

A dictionary of scalar variable names and indices associated with this collection of entities.

This object is a mapping of scalar variable name -> index, that are active on the collection of entities.

Prefer using fields() which is usually more convenient unless you only want one component, because each variable is only a scalar, and maybe a component value of a field vector or tensor.

Example

Get the Z component of a force variable at a single node at all times.

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     node_vars = e.nodal.variables
>>>     fz = e.nodal.variable_at_times(node_vars['AForceZ'], 1, 0, e.globals.times().size)
>>>     print(fz)
Return type:Dict[str, int]
Returns:A collections.OrderedDict, where keys of the dictionary are variable names, and the values of the dictionary are the integer index, or ID of the variable.

class affect.exodus.Blocks(self, database_id=-1, block_type=None, *args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: affect.exodus.EntityDictionaryWithProperty, affect.exodus.EntityCollectionWithVariable

  • block_type – the type of the entity, one of ELEM_BLOCK, EDGE_BLOCK, or FACE_BLOCK
Raises:

InvalidEntityType – if the block_type is invalid.
clear() → None. Remove all items from D.¶
connectivity_local_all(self, keys=None, entry_type=EntryType.NODE, compress=False)¶

Construct a generator that can be used to iterate over the local connectivity of each block.

The next() of the iterator returns a tuple (key, block, local_connectivity).

If a block has no connected entries, the local_connectivity returned will be None.

Using this iterator avoids repeatedly allocating, zeroing, and freeing some temporary memory used to compute local connectivity arrays. This method is more efficient than calling Block.connectivity_local() for each block separately.

See Block.connectivity_local() for more.

Parameters:
  • keys (Iterable[int]) – an ordered sequence of Block keys to use, which is a subset of all the Blocks (as opposed to all the Blocks which is the default)
  • entry_type – (default EntryType.NODE) type of entries returned in the connectivity array, one of NODE, EDGE, FACE
  • compress – if False (default) return a numpy.ndarray, if True return a compressed array in affect.util.CompressedArray
Returns:

connectivity_local_iterator - an iterator over tuples of (key, block, local_connectivity), where key

is the block ID, block is a Block, and local_connectivity is a LocalConnectivity
Raises:
  • EntityKeyError – if keys is not None and one of the keys is not present in the database.
  • InvalidEntityType – if the connect entry_type does not make sense
  • MaxLengthExceeded – if the number of unique local nodes in this block exceeds UINT32_MAX, 2^32 - 1,
fields¶

A dictionary of fields associated with this collection of entities.

This object is a mapping of field names to Field objects that are active on the collection of entities.

Each field is a grouping of ExodusII variable by common name prefix; the suffix of the variable name (whatever follows the last underscore ‘_’ in the name) becomes a component name.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     print(f'number of nodal fields: {len(e.nodal.fields)}')
>>>     print(f'element field names: {e.globals.fields.keys()}')
>>>     for f in e.element_blocks.fields.values():
>>>         print(f)
Return type:Dict[str, Field]
Returns:A collections.OrderedDict, where keys of the dictionary are field names, and the values of the dictionary are instances of Field.

name_ids()¶

A dictionary of the mapping of entity name to entity id for every entity in this group.

This method is a convenience for direct lookup and indexing entity ID’s only by their name, which is often not needed. Using an iterator through he keys and items of this class is probably more useful.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     element_blocks = e.element_blocks
>>>     name_ids = element_blocks.name_ids()
>>>     block_id = name_ids['block_1']
>>>     block = element_blocks[block_id]
>>>     print(block)

One of the element blocks is accessed by string name “block_1”, which may be different depending on the individual ExodusII database file.

Return type:Dict[str, int]
Returns:a dictionary of name keys to entity_id values

None if this is a Nodal or Global

update([E, ]**F) → None. Update D from mapping/iterable E and F.¶

If E present and has a .keys() method, does: for k in E: D[k] = E[k] If E present and lacks .keys() method, does: for (k, v) in E: D[k] = v In either case, this is followed by: for k, v in F.items(): D[k] = v

variables¶

A dictionary of scalar variable names and indices associated with this collection of entities.

This object is a mapping of scalar variable name -> index, that are active on the collection of entities.

Prefer using fields() which is usually more convenient unless you only want one component, because each variable is only a scalar, and maybe a component value of a field vector or tensor.

Example

Get the Z component of a force variable at a single node at all times.

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     node_vars = e.nodal.variables
>>>     fz = e.nodal.variable_at_times(node_vars['AForceZ'], 1, 0, e.globals.times().size)
>>>     print(fz)
Return type:Dict[str, int]
Returns:A collections.OrderedDict, where keys of the dictionary are variable names, and the values of the dictionary are the integer index, or ID of the variable.
class affect.exodus.Block(self, database_id=-1, block_type=None, block_id=-1, name=None, topology_name=None, num_entries=0, num_nodes_per_entry=0, num_edges_per_entry=0, num_faces_per_entry=0, attribute_names=None, parent_entity_collection=None, *args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: affect.exodus.EntityWithAttribute, affect.exodus.EntityWithProperty

A block of entries — elements, faces, or edges of the same topology — with connectivity information.

Parameters:
  • block_type (int) – entity type of the block, one of EDGE_BLOCK, FACE_BLOCK, ELEM_BLOCK
  • block_id (int) – unique integer identifier
  • name (str) – name of the block
  • topology_name (str) – topology_name of the entries in the block
  • num_entries (int) – number of the entries in this block: nodes, edges, faces, or elements
  • num_nodes_per_entry (int) – number of nodes per topology_name
  • num_edges_per_entry (int) – number of edges per topology_name
  • num_faces_per_entry (int) – number of edges per topology_name
  • attribute_names (Iterable(str)) – iterable collection of attribute names
  • parent_entity_collection (Blocks) – the containing blocks object
Raises:
  • InvalidEntityType – if entity_type is not one of EDGE_BLOCK, FACE_BOCK or ELEM_BLOCK
  • ArgumentTypeError – if the attribute_names is not None and a list could not be created from them
attribute(attrib_index)¶

Read an array of values of a single attribute for all entries in the given collection.

Parameters:attrib_index (int) – desired attribute in range [0, num_attribute-1].
Return type:ndarray
Returns:Array of type numpy.double with shape (num_entries), or

None if this type of entity does not support attributes
attribute_names()¶

Read the attribute names on a single entity.

Attribute names were added to the Exodus API library in version 4.26; databases written earlier than that will return empty strings.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size num_attribute * (8 + cexodus.EX_INQ_MAX_READ_NAME_LENGTH + 1) bytes.

Return type:List[str]
Returns:list of string names
attribute_partial(start, stop, attrib_index)¶

Read one entity attribute for a subsection of entries in the given collection.

Parameters:
  • start (int) – first local entry index at which attributes are desired, in the range [0, num_entry - 1].
  • stop (int) – one past the end of the last desired local entry index, in the range [start+1, num_entry].
  • attrib_index (int) – desired attribute in range [0, num_attribute-1]
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

Array of attribute values of type numpy.double with shape (stop - start) or

None if there are no entries or this entity type does not support attributes

Read all the attribute values for all the entries in the given collection.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:array of numpy.double with shape (num_entries, num_attribute)

connectivity(entry_type=<EntryType.NODE: 66>, zero_based=True, compress=False)¶

Read an array of the entries-to-node connectivity for a given block.

The enumeration of the connected entries are zero based, unless zero_based is set to False, in which case the entries begin at one.

Parameters:
  • entry_type – (default EntryType.NODE) type of entries returned in the connectivity array, one of NODE, EDGE, FACE
  • zero_based – if True (default) the enumeration of the connected entries begins at zero
  • compress – if False (default) return a numpy.ndarray, if True return a compressed array in affect.util.CompressedArray
Return type:

Union[ndarray, CompressedArray]
Returns:

Array of integer type with shape (num_entry, num_conn_entries), for example, when entry_type is NODE, conn[i,j] is the jth node of the ith entry in the block; or

None if there are no entries
Raises:

InvalidEntityType – if the connect entry_type does not make sense
connectivity_local(entry_type=<EntryType.NODE: 66>, compress=False)¶

An array of the entries-to-local-node connectivity for a given block.

This returns an enumeration of the node IDs connected to entries in the range (0, num_local_nodes), where num_local_nodes in the number of unique global nodes connected to entries in this block only. The local nodes are always enumerated starting with zero.

The local node connectivity array uses unsigned 32 bit integers, limiting the unique local nodes in the block to 4,294,967,295. For a rough estimate, for a cube shaped block of HEX8 elements with this many unique nodes, reaching this limit would mean the element-to-local-node array requires 137 GB of memory, and the local-to-global mapping from (local to global node ID) requires 34 GB of memory.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer up to the size num_global_nodes * 8 bytes. For more than four billion global nodes this requires more than 32 GB.

Parameters:
  • entry_type – (default EntryType.NODE) type of entries returned in the connectivity array, one of NODE, EDGE, FACE
  • compress – if False (default) do not store the data of the LocalConnectivity instance in compressed form, if True, internal storage of the instance of LocalConnectivity uses affect.util.CompressedArray
Return type:

LocalConnectivity
Returns:

local_connectivity - instance of LocalConnectivity, with an array of local_nodes of shape (num_entry, num_conn_entries) and global_nodes of shape (num_local_nodes,)
Raises:
  • InvalidEntityType – if the connect entry_type does not make sense
  • MaxLengthExceeded – if the number of unique local nodes in this block exceeds UINT32_MAX, 2^32 - 1,
connectivity_partial(start, stop, entry_type=<EntryType.NODE: 66>, zero_based=True)¶

Read an array of a subsection of the entries-to-node connectivity for a given block.

The enumeration of the connected entries are zero based, unless zero_based is set to False, in which case the entries begin at one.

Parameters:
  • start (int) – first local element index at which nodes are desired, in the range [0, num_entry - 1].
  • stop (int) – one past the end of the last desired local entry index, in the range [start+1, num_entry]
  • entry_type (EntryType) – (default EntryType.NODE) type of entries returned in the connectivity array, one of EntryType.NODE, EntryType.EDGE, EntryType.FACE
  • zero_based (bool) – if True (default) the enumeration of the connected entries in the array begins at 0, if False, entries start at 1.
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

An array of numpy.int with shape (num_entry, num_conn_entries), for example, when entry_type is NODE, array entry [i,j] is the jth node of the ith entry in the block; or

None if there are no entries
Raises:

RangeError – if the start, stop range is invalid
field(field, time_step)¶

Read the array of field values of a single field at a time step for all entries.

Uses a temporarily allocated buffer of size num_entries * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the desired field (name and component names)
  • time_step (int) – the time step index, at which the field component values are desired, the first time step is 0; a value of -1 will return the values at the last time step.
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

a byte aligned array of numpy.float64 values with shape (num_entries, len(field.components)), or

None if num_entries == 0 or field is not associated with ExodusII variable indices.
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
field_at_times(field, entry_index, start_time_step, stop_time_step)¶

Read an array of values of a field for a single entry (node, element, edge, face) on a range of time steps.

The entry_index has the following meaning inside this method:

entity_type entry_index
NODAL a global node index
BLOCK local entry index of the associated entries
SET local entry index of the associated entries
GLOBAL ignored

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size num_time * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the desired field (name and component names)
  • entry_index (int) – index of the desired entry in the entity, in range [0, num_entries-1]
  • start_time_step (int) – starting time step, in range [0, num_times]
  • stop_time_step (int) – one past the end of the last time step, use -1 to indicate the final time step
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

array of numpy.float64 values with

shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step, len(field.components)) if len(field.components) > 1, or

shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step) if len(field.components) == 1.
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
field_partial(field, time_step, start_entry, stop_entry)¶

Read an array of values of a single field on a subsection of the entries on an entity.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size (stop_entry - start_entry) * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the field
  • time_step (int) – the time time_step index, which the object variable values are desired, the first time time_step is 0.
  • start_entry (int) – first entry at which field is read, in the range of [0, num_entry-1].
  • stop_entry (int) – one past the end of the last desired entry at which the field is read, in the range of [start_entry+1, num_entry]
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

array with shape (stop_entry - start_entry, len(field.components)) of numpy.double
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
is_field_active()¶

Read the array of one or zero values indicating whether each entity field exists on this entity.

All variables on Nodal and Global entities are always active. Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer up to the size num_vars * 8 bytes.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:An array with shape len(num_vars,) of type numpy.int32, or

None if no variables are present.
Raises:InactiveComponent – if components of one of the fields are not all active or all inactive.
is_variable_active()¶

Read an array of one or zero values indicating whether each variable exists or not, respectively, for a single associated entity.

All variables on nodal and global entities are always active.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:array of numpy.int32 with shape (num_vars,), or

None if no variables are present.
num_attributes()¶

The number of attributes on a single collection entity.

Only NODAL, EDGE_BLOCK, FACE_BLOCK, ELEM_BLOCK, NODE_SET, EDGE_SET, FACE_SET, SIDE_SET, ELEM_SET have attributes.

Return type:int
Returns:Number of attributes
num_entries()¶

The number of entries contained within a single collection entity.

For example return the number of elements in an element block, or return number of faces in a face set, etc.

entity_type range of num_entries
GLOBAL 1
NODAL number of global nodes
EDGE_BLOCK, FACE_BLOCK, ELEM_BLOCK number of edges, faces, or elements in the block, respectively
NODE_SET, EDGE_SET, FACE_SET, ELEM_SET number of nodes, edges, faces, or elements in the set, respectively
SIDE_SET number of element sides in the side set
NODE_MAP, EDGE_MAP, FACE_MAP, ELEM_MAP number of global nodes, edges, faces, or elements, respectively
Return type:int
Returns:number of entries associated with the entity
Raises:InvalidEntityType – if entity_type of this collection is invalid or does not support entries
property(property_name)¶

The value of a property on a given entity collection.

Properties are integer values associated with an entity.

Parameters:property_name (str) – name of the property
Return type:int
Returns:An integer property value.
topology_name¶

The name of the uniform topology of all elements in the block.

Return type:str
Returns:Unambiguous name of the element topology as an uppercase string.
variable(variable_index, time_step)¶

Read the array of values of a single variable at a given time step.

Parameters:
  • variable_index (int) – index of the desired variable, indices start at 0, in range [0, num_variables-1]
  • time_step (int) – the time step index, which the object variable values are desired, the first time step is 0.
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

array with shape (num_entries,) of type numpy.float64, or

None if there are no entries.
variable_at_times(variable_index, entry_index, start_time_step, stop_time_step)¶

Read the array of values of a single variable on a range of time steps.

The entry_index has the following meaning, for a Nodal entity it is a global node index, for Block and Set this is a the local entry index.

The entry_index is ignored for the Global entity.

Parameters:
  • variable_index (int) – index of the desired variable, indices start at 0, in range [0, num_variables-1]
  • entry_index (int) – index of the desired entry in the Entity, in range [0, num_entries-1]
  • start_time_step (int) – starting time step, in range [0, num_times]
  • stop_time_step (int) – one past the end of the last time step, use -1 to indicate the final time step
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

array with shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step) of numpy.float64 or

None if there are no entries
variable_partial(var_index, time_step, start_entry, stop_entry)¶

Read the array of values of a single variable on a subsection of the entries on an entity.

Parameters:
  • var_index (int) – index of the desired variable, indices start at 0, in range [0, num_variables-1]
  • time_step (int) – the time time_step index, which the object variable values are desired, the first time time_step is 0.
  • start_entry (int) – first entry at which variables are read, in the range of [0, num_entry-1].
  • stop_entry (int) – one past the end of the last desired entry at which the variable is read, in the range of [start_entry+1, num_entry]
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

array of type numpy.double with shape (stop_entry - start_entry) or

None if there are no entries.

Sets Entities¶

class affect.exodus.Sets(self, database_id=-1, set_type=None, *args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: affect.exodus.EntityDictionaryWithProperty, affect.exodus.EntityCollectionWithVariable

A collection of all the Set entities of a specific type on a Database.

An ordered dictionary of all ( set_id, Set ) pairs, based on the set concept.

Parameters:
  • database_id (int) – ID of the Exodus database.
  • set_type (EntityType) – (default None) the type of the contained sets, one of ELEM_SET, NODE_SET, SIDE_SET, EDGE_SET, or FACE_SET
Raises:

InvalidEntityType – if the set_type is invalid
clear() → None. Remove all items from D.¶
fields¶

A dictionary of fields associated with this collection of entities.

This object is a mapping of field names to Field objects that are active on the collection of entities.

Each field is a grouping of ExodusII variable by common name prefix; the suffix of the variable name (whatever follows the last underscore ‘_’ in the name) becomes a component name.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     print(f'number of nodal fields: {len(e.nodal.fields)}')
>>>     print(f'element field names: {e.globals.fields.keys()}')
>>>     for f in e.element_blocks.fields.values():
>>>         print(f)
Return type:Dict[str, Field]
Returns:A collections.OrderedDict, where keys of the dictionary are field names, and the values of the dictionary are instances of Field.
get(k[, d]) → D[k] if k in D, else d. d defaults to None.¶
is_variable_active_all()¶

Read a table of indicating whether each of the variables on this type of entities is active on each entity.

A value of one in a table entry indicate a variable exists, while a value of zero indicates the variable does not exist on an entity.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:Array of type numpy.int32, with shape (num_entity, num_vars), with one or zero entries indicating the variable is active on an entity.

None if no variables are present on any entities of this type.
items() → a set-like object providing a view on D's items¶
keys() → a set-like object providing a view on D's keys¶
name(entity_id)¶

Read the name of one entity in an association or collection.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of up to size cexodus.EX_INQ_MAX_READ_NAME_LENGTH + 1 bytes.

Parameters:entity_id (int) – the integer ID of an entity in the association or collection.
Return type:str
Returns:Name of the Set, Block, or Map object, given by the ID, or an empty string if this is a Global or Nodal.
name_ids()¶

A dictionary of the mapping of entity name to entity id for every entity in this group.

This method is a convenience for direct lookup and indexing entity ID’s only by their name, which is often not needed. Using an iterator through he keys and items of this class is probably more useful.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     element_blocks = e.element_blocks
>>>     name_ids = element_blocks.name_ids()
>>>     block_id = name_ids['block_1']
>>>     block = element_blocks[block_id]
>>>     print(block)

One of the element blocks is accessed by string name “block_1”, which may be different depending on the individual ExodusII database file.

Return type:Dict[str, int]
Returns:a dictionary of name keys to entity_id values
names()¶

Read all the names of the entities in this association or collection.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of up to size num_objects * (8 + cexodus.EX_INQ_MAX_READ_NAME_LENGTH + 1) bytes.

Return type:List[str]
Returns:List of names of all the Set, Block, or Map objects in this collection, or an empty list this is a Global or Nodal or

None if this is a Nodal or Global

as a 2-tuple; but raise KeyError if D is empty.

setdefault(k[, d]) → D.get(k,d), also set D[k]=d if k not in D¶
sum_entries()¶

Get the total count of all associated entries summed over all collections of entities of this type in the database.

Return type:int
Returns:The count of any and all entries related to entities of this type.
self.entity_type Return value
EntityType.GLOBAL 1 (always)
EntityType.NODAL 1 (always)
EntityType.NODE_MAP sum of count of nodes in all node maps
EntityType.EDGE_MAP sum of count of edges in all edge maps
EntityType.FACE_MAP sum of count of faces in all face maps
EntityType.ELEM_MAP sum of count of elements in all element maps
EntityType.NODE_SET sum of count of nodes in all node sets
EntityType.EDGE_SET sum of count of edges in all edge sets
EntityType.FACE_SET sum of count of faces in all face sets
EntityType.ELEM_SET sum of count of elements in all element sets
EntityType.SIDE_SET (sum of count of elements, sum of count of nodes) in all side sets
update([E, ]**F) → None. Update D from mapping/iterable E and F.¶

If E present and has a .keys() method, does: for k in E: D[k] = E[k] If E present and lacks .keys() method, does: for (k, v) in E: D[k] = v In either case, this is followed by: for k, v in F.items(): D[k] = v

values() → an object providing a view on D's values¶
variable_name(variable_index)¶

The name of a variable associated with this entity_type.

A variable is scalar only. Multiple variables make up a vector or tensor field.

Parameters:variable_index (int) – variable index in the range [0,num_variables - 1]
Return type:str
Returns:Name of the variable with the given index.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of up to size num_variables * (8 + cexodus.MAX_STR_LENGTH + 1) bytes.

Return type:List[str]
Returns:List of variable names.

A dictionary of scalar variable names and indices associated with this collection of entities.

This object is a mapping of scalar variable name -> index, that are active on the collection of entities.

Prefer using fields() which is usually more convenient unless you only want one component, because each variable is only a scalar, and maybe a component value of a field vector or tensor.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('/tmp/myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     node_vars = e.nodal.variables
>>>     fz = e.nodal.variable_at_times(node_vars['AForceZ'], 1, 0, e.globals.times().size)

class affect.exodus.Set(self, database_id=1, set_type=None, set_id=-1, name=None, num_entries=0, num_dist_fact=0, attribute_names=None, parent_entity_collection=None, *args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: affect.exodus.EntityWithAttribute, affect.exodus.EntityWithProperty

A set of entries in a Database.

The set may contain attributes, properties and distribution factors.

Parameters:
  • database_id (int) – ID of the Exodus database.
  • set_type (EntityType) – (default None) the type of the entities collected, one of NODE_SET, SIDE_SET, EDGE_SET, FACE_SET, ELEM_SET
  • set_id (int) – ID of the set
  • name (str) – name of the set
  • num_entries (int) – (default 0) number of the entries in this set: nodes, sides, edges, faces, or elements
  • num_dist_fact (int) – (default 0) number of distribution factors on this set
  • attribute_names (Iterable[str]) – names of the attributes on this set
  • parent_entity_collection (Sets) – (default None) the parent Sets collection
Raises:
  • InvalidEntityType – if the set_type is invalid
  • ArgumentTypeError – if the attribute_names is not None and a list could not be created from them

Return type:ndarray

distribution_factors()¶

Read the distribution factors for the entries in this set.

A special scalar variable, distribution factors can be associated with a set collection type. There is either zero or one distribution factors on a given set.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:Array of type numpy.double with shape (num_entries,), or

None if no distribution factors exist.
distribution_factors_partial(start, stop)¶

Read the distribution factors for a subsection of the entries in a given set.

Parameters:
  • start (int) – first entry at which variables are read, must be in the range of [0, num_entry-1].
  • stop (int) – one past the end of the last desired entry at which the factor is read, must be in the range of [start+1, num_entry].
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

Array of type numpy.double with shape (stop - start,), or

None if no distribution factors exists
entries(self, zero_based=True)¶

Read an array of numbers that identifying the members of the set.

The return value is different when it is a EntityType.SIDE_SET.

set_type return value
SIDE_SET two arrays of size num_entries, [i] is the the ith element number, [j] is the jth local side
NODE_SET array of size num_entries, [i] is the ith node number in the set
ELEM_SET array of size num_entries, [i] is the ith element number in the set
FACE_SET array of size num_entries, [i] is the ith face number in the set
EDGE_SET array of size num_entries, [i] is the ith edge number in the set

May use temporary allocated buffers up to size num_entries * 8 bytes when set_type == SIDE_SET.

Parameters:zero_based – (default=True) False if entry ID’s beginning at 1 are desired.
Returns:set_entries(ndarray[uint32_t, ndim=1, mode="c"]) - array of entry IDs of size (num_entries), or
set_entries(ndarray[uint32_t, ndim=1, mode="c"]), set_sides(ndarray[int8_t, ndim=1, mode="c"]) - array of element entries IDs and array of local element
sides, both size (num_entries)
field(field, time_step)¶

Read the array of field values of a single field at a time step for all entries.

Uses a temporarily allocated buffer of size num_entries * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the desired field (name and component names)
  • time_step (int) – the time step index, at which the field component values are desired, the first time step is 0; a value of -1 will return the values at the last time step.
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

a byte aligned array of numpy.float64 values with shape (num_entries, len(field.components)), or

None if num_entries == 0 or field is not associated with ExodusII variable indices.
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
field_at_times(field, entry_index, start_time_step, stop_time_step)¶

Read an array of values of a field for a single entry (node, element, edge, face) on a range of time steps.

The entry_index has the following meaning inside this method:

entity_type entry_index
NODAL a global node index
BLOCK local entry index of the associated entries
SET local entry index of the associated entries
GLOBAL ignored

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size num_time * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the desired field (name and component names)
  • entry_index (int) – index of the desired entry in the entity, in range [0, num_entries-1]
  • start_time_step (int) – starting time step, in range [0, num_times]
  • stop_time_step (int) – one past the end of the last time step, use -1 to indicate the final time step
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

array of numpy.float64 values with

shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step, len(field.components)) if len(field.components) > 1, or

shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step) if len(field.components) == 1.
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
field_partial(field, time_step, start_entry, stop_entry)¶

Read an array of values of a single field on a subsection of the entries on an entity.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of size (stop_entry - start_entry) * 8 bytes.

Parameters:
  • field (Field) – the field
  • time_step (int) – the time time_step index, which the object variable values are desired, the first time time_step is 0.
  • start_entry (int) – first entry at which field is read, in the range of [0, num_entry-1].
  • stop_entry (int) – one past the end of the last desired entry at which the field is read, in the range of [start_entry+1, num_entry]
Return type:

FieldArray
Returns:

array with shape (stop_entry - start_entry, len(field.components)) of numpy.double
Raises:

InactiveField – if the given field does not exist on this entity.
is_field_active()¶

Read the array of one or zero values indicating whether each entity field exists on this entity.

All variables on Nodal and Global entities are always active. Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer up to the size num_vars * 8 bytes.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:An array with shape len(num_vars,) of type numpy.int32, or

None if no variables are present.
Raises:InactiveComponent – if components of one of the fields are not all active or all inactive.

Read an array of one or zero values indicating whether each variable exists or not, respectively, for a single associated entity.

All variables on nodal and global entities are always active.

Return type:ndarray
Returns:array of numpy.int32 with shape (num_vars,), or

None if no variables are present.

entity_type range of num_entries
GLOBAL 1
NODAL number of global nodes
EDGE_BLOCK, FACE_BLOCK, ELEM_BLOCK number of edges, faces, or elements in the block, respectively
NODE_SET, EDGE_SET, FACE_SET, ELEM_SET number of nodes, edges, faces, or elements in the set, respectively

variable_at_times(variable_index, entry_index, start_time_step, stop_time_step)¶

Read the array of values of a single variable on a range of time steps.

The entry_index has the following meaning, for a Nodal entity it is a global node index, for Block and Set this is a the local entry index.

The entry_index is ignored for the Global entity.

Parameters:
  • variable_index (int) – index of the desired variable, indices start at 0, in range [0, num_variables-1]
  • entry_index (int) – index of the desired entry in the Entity, in range [0, num_entries-1]
  • start_time_step (int) – starting time step, in range [0, num_times]
  • stop_time_step (int) – one past the end of the last time step, use -1 to indicate the final time step
Return type:

ndarray
Returns:

array with shape (stop_time_step - start_time_step) of numpy.float64 or

None if there are no entries

Read the name of one entity in an association or collection.

Parameters:entity_id (int) – the integer ID of an entity in the association or collection.

name_ids()¶

A dictionary of the mapping of entity name to entity id for every entity in this group.

This method is a convenience for direct lookup and indexing entity ID’s only by their name, which is often not needed. Using an iterator through he keys and items of this class is probably more useful.

Example

>>> with DatabaseFile('myExodusFile.exo') as e:
>>>     element_blocks = e.element_blocks
>>>     name_ids = element_blocks.name_ids()
>>>     block_id = name_ids['block_1']
>>>     block = element_blocks[block_id]
>>>     print(block)

One of the element blocks is accessed by string name “block_1”, which may be different depending on the individual ExodusII database file.

Return type:Dict[str, int]
Returns:a dictionary of name keys to entity_id values
names()¶

Read all the names of the entities in this association or collection.

Uses an internal temporary allocated buffer of up to size num_objects * (8 + cexodus.EX_INQ_MAX_READ_NAME_LENGTH + 1) bytes.

Return type:List[str]
Returns:List of names of all the Set, Block, or Map objects in this collection, or an empty list this is a Global or Nodal or

None if this is a Nodal or Global

self.entity_type Return value
EntityType.GLOBAL 1 (always)
EntityType.NODAL 1 (always)

EntityType.EDGE_MAP sum of count of edges in all edge maps
EntityType.FACE_MAP sum of count of faces in all face maps
EntityType.ELEM_MAP sum of count of elements in all element maps

EntityType.ELEM_SET sum of count of elements in all element sets
EntityType.SIDE_SET (sum of count of elements, sum of count of nodes) in all side sets
update([E, ]**F) → None. Update D from mapping/iterable E and F.¶

If E present and has a .keys() method, does: for k in E: D[k] = E[k] If E present and lacks .keys() method, does: for (k, v) in E: D[k] = v In either case, this is followed by: for k, v in F.items(): D[k] = v

values() → an object providing a view on D's values¶

Fields¶

affect.exodus.Component = indicates either a str or int¶

Type variable.

Usage:

T = TypeVar('T')  # Can be anything
A = TypeVar('A', str, bytes)  # Must be str or bytes

Type variables exist primarily for the benefit of static type checkers. They serve as the parameters for generic types as well as for generic function definitions. See class Generic for more information on generic types. Generic functions work as follows:

def repeat(x: T, n: int) -> List[T]:
‘’‘Return a list containing n references to x.’‘’ return [x]*n
def longest(x: A, y: A) -> A:
‘’‘Return the longest of two strings.’‘’ return x if len(x) >= len(y) else y

The latter example’s signature is essentially the overloading of (str, str) -> str and (bytes, bytes) -> bytes. Also note that if the arguments are instances of some subclass of str, the return type is still plain str.

At runtime, isinstance(x, T) and issubclass(C, T) will raise TypeError.

Type variables defined with covariant=True or contravariant=True can be used do declare covariant or contravariant generic types. See PEP 484 for more details. By default generic types are invariant in all type variables.

Type variables can be introspected. e.g.:

T.__name__ == ‘T’ T.__constraints__ == () T.__covariant__ == False T.__contravariant__ = False A.__constraints__ == (str, bytes)
class affect.exodus.Field(self, name, components, variables=None, parent_field_dictionary=None)¶

Bases: object

A field name, number and name of components, and the ExodusII variable ID for each component.

The method in which ExodusII stores a multi-component field is by storing multiple scalar variables — the scalar variable names associated with a field have the same starting prefix. This class makes it easy to access the data in multiple variables as one FieldArray.

The array values of the field components are accessed through the member functions of the associated entity on which the field is active.

Fields may be associated with an entity of type GLOBAL, NODAL, NODE_SET, EDGE_BLOCK, EDGE_SET, FACE_BLOCK, FACE_SET, ELEM_BLOCK, ELEM_SET, or SIDE_SET.

Parameters:
  • name (str) – base name of the field, without trailing subscripts
  • components (Sequence[~Component]) – a sequence containing names of the subscripts of the field components, for example, either containing all str ('xx', 'yy', 'zz', 'xy', 'xz', 'yz'), or containing all int [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7].
  • variables (Sequence[int]) – a sequence of variable indices in the Exodus database corresponding to the scalars storing the components with length equal to len(components)
  • parent_field_dictionary (Fields) – the collection of fields that this Field object belongs to
Raises:

ArrayTypeError – if components less than one, or components not equal to associated variable dimensions
class affect.exodus.Fields(self, parent_entity_collection)¶

Bases: collections.abc.MutableMapping

An accessor for fields, acting as an ordered dictionary with some extra member functions.

For a database, this is an accessor for the fields on all the members of one type of entity in a database. The set of entities are one of the globals, the nodal, or one of element blocks, face blocks, or edge blocks; or side sets, node sets, element sets, face sets, or edge sets.

The keys of the dictionary are the base names of fields.

Parameters:parent_entity_collection (EntityCollectionWithVariable) – if reading/modifying an existing database, the owning collection of entities in an Exodus database, one of a Global, Nodal, Blocks, or Sets object
Raises:InvalidEntityType – if the parent collection of entities does not support fields

class affect.exodus.FieldArray¶

Bases: numpy.ndarray

A multidimensional array of double precision, which is a specialization of NumPy array.

It holds a Field object for the field name and the names of its components.

The constructor requires an already formed numpy.ndarray instance (from any of the usual numpy constructors) and optionally a Field instance. The len(info.components) must equal input_array.shape[-1]. The input_array.dtype must be numpy.double or numpy.float64.

Example

>>> pos_info = Field('position', ('x', 'y', 'z'))
>>> arr = numpy.empty(3, dtype=numpy.double)
>>> obj = FieldArray(arr, pos_info)
>>> type(obj)
<class 'FieldArray'>
>>> obj.info.name
'position'
>>> len(obj.info.components)
3
>>> v = obj[1:]
>>> type(v)
<class 'FieldArray'>
>>> len(v.info.components)
3

You can use either the FieldArray.empty() or FieldArray.zeros() class factory to produce a FieldArray with given Field information and a number of entries.

Example

>>> my_coordinate_array = FieldArray.empty(Field('coordinates', ('x', 'y', 'z')), 256)
>>> my_coordinate_array.shape
(3, 256)

FieldArray.__new__(cls, input_array, info=None)
